engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) L134 Go-Devil I4 (60 hp gross, 54 hp net)
notes: Iconic WWII quarter-ton military Jeep (1,200 lb payload). 80-inch wheelbase, 3-4 person capacity. 15-gallon fuel tank, 300-mile range, 65 mph max speed. Live axles with leaf springs front and rear. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. Military-grade construction requiring vintage vehicle and military equipment expertise. Highly collectible wartime vehicle with specialized maintenance requirements. Difficulty modifier reflects WWII-era technology, parts scarcity, and historical preservation standards. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys MB article, January 2025 revision.

First full-production civilian Jeep. Total production of 214,760 units. Civilianized version of military MB with seven-slot grille (vs. nine-slot MB). 80-inch wheelbase. Available in multiple colors (Pasture Green, Harvest Tan). Agricultural and industrial options available. Leaf spring suspension, Dana axles. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. 1940s-era vintage vehicle requiring specialized restoration and maintenance expertise. Difficulty modifier reflects post-war technology and collectible status. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

Introduced 1949 as successor to CJ-2A. Total production of 131,843 units (1949-1953). One-piece windshield with bottom vent, beefed-up 10-leaf suspension. 80-inch wheelbase. Farm Jeep and Jeep Tractor versions available. Leaf spring suspension, Dana axles. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. Late 1940s vintage vehicle requiring specialized knowledge. Difficulty modifier reflects vintage technology and collectible status. Data sourced from Wikipedia Jeep CJ article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) L-134 Go-Devil flathead I4
notes: Introduced July 1946 as first mass-market all-steel station wagon. Designed by Brooks Stevens. Independent front suspension with transverse seven-leaf 'Planadyne' spring system. Panel van introduced 1947 (one seat, doors instead of tailgate, no rear side windows). Initially RWD only, 4WD option added 1949. 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. 1940s vintage vehicle with unique suspension system requiring specialized expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys Jeep Station Wagon article, January 2025 revision.

engines: 2.2L (134 cu in) Go-Devil L4-134 side-valve I4 (63 hp)
notes: Introduced 1947 based on Station Wagon and CJ-2A. 118-inch wheelbase. 4T model (1-ton 4WD) and 2T model (Â¾-ton 2WD, by 1949). Final drive ratios: 5.38:1 standard, 4.88:1 and 6.17:1 optional. Various body configurations: pickup, stake truck, cab/chassis, bare chassis. Leaf spring suspension, 6-volt electrical system, manual choke carburetor, points-based ignition. Late 1940s vintage commercial vehicle requiring specialized knowledge. Data sourced from Wikipedia Willys Jeep Truck article, January 2025 revision.
